intro: Amphicarpaea bracteata, commonly known as the narrowleaf false flax, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Fabaceae family, which includes legumes, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant produces two types of fruits: one above ground and one below ground, a unique adaptation known as amphicarpy. Its root system is capable of fixing nitrogen, contributing to soil fertility. This species thrives in wetland habitats and is often found in moist, sandy soils.
